revision.comment: Robot - Moving category United States Marine Corps in popular culture to [[:Category:Popular culture about the United States Marine Corps]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 23]].
revision.text:
{{for|the 2006 film adaptation|Flags of Our Fathers (film)}} {{Infobox book | |name = Flags of Our Fathers |image = Image:FlagsOfOurFathers.jpg |caption = First edition cover |author = [[James Bradley (author)|James Bradley]]
[[Ron Powers]] |cover_artist = |country = United States |language = English |genre = [[Non-fiction]] |publisher = [[Bantam Books]] |release_date = 2000 |media_type = [[Printing|Print]] |pages = |isbn = 0-553-11133-7 }} '''''Flags of Our Fathers''''' (2000) is a ''[[New York Times]]'' bestselling book by [[James Bradley (author)|James Bradley]] with [[Ron Powers]] about the six [[United States Marines]] who would eventually be made famous by [[Joe Rosenthal]]'s lauded photograph of the [[Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima|flag raising at Iwo Jima]], one of the costliest and most horrifying battles of [[World War II]]'s [[Pacific Ocean theater of World War II|Pacific Theater]]. The flag raisers were [[Harold Schultz]], [[Rene Gagnon]], [[Ira Hayes]], [[Mike Strank]], [[Harlon Block]], and [[Franklin Sousley]]; the latter three men died later in the battle. Strank was a [[Sergeant]] who refused several promotions during the battle in order to "Bring his boys back to their mothers." Block was a [[Corporal]] who reported to Strank, and the rest were [[Private (rank)|Privates]] in the Marines, except for [[John Bradley (United States Navy)|John Bradley]], a Navy Corpsman who administered first aid to Easy [[Company (military unit)|Company]] of 2nd [[Battalion]], [[28th Marines]], [[5th Marine Division]], the company to which all the flag raisers were assigned.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/b/bradley-flags.html |publisher=[[The New York Times]]|author=James Bradley|author2=Ron Powers|title=Flags of Our Fathers|year=2000}} The book, published in May 2000 by [[Bantam Books]], a division of [[Random House]], spent 46 weeks on the ''[[New York Times]]'' nonfiction bestseller list, spending six weeks at number one. Shortly after the book's publication, Steven Spielberg acquired the option on the film rights for [[DreamWorks Pictures]]. The book follows the lives of the six flag-raisers through their early lives of innocence, military training, fierce combat and afterward, when they were sent on tours to raise money for [[war bond]]s. The film adaptation ''[[Flags of Our Fathers (film)|Flags of Our Fathers]]'', which opened in the U.S. on October 20, 2006, was directed by [[Clint Eastwood]] and produced by [[Steven Spielberg]], with a screenplay written by [[William Broyles, Jr.]] and [[Paul Haggis]]. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links == *[http://www.efilmcritic.com/feature.php?feature=2004 eFilmCritic.com interview with James Bradley about ''Flags of Our Fathers''] *[https://www.c-span.org/video/?157386-1/flags-fathers ''Booknotes'' interview with Bradley on ''Flags of Our Fathers'', July 9, 2000.] {{DEFAULTSORT:Flags Of Our Fathers}} [[Category:2000 books]] [[Category:Bantam Books books]] [[Category:Battle of Iwo Jima]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Popular culture about the United States Marine Corps]] [[Category:World War II memoirs]] {{US-mil-hist-book-stub}} {{WWII-book-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Follow Me Home | director = Peter Bratt | writer = Peter Bratt | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Alfre Woodard]] * [[Jesse Borrego]] * [[Benjamin Bratt]] * Calvin Levels * Steve Reevis}} | released = {{Film date|1996}} | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Follow Me Home''''' is a 1996 film directed by activist and filmmaker Peter Bratt. It explores spiritual and intercultural race relations through the lives of four artists, one African American, one Native American and two [[Latin-American]] cousins, who embark on a cross-country road trip to paint a mural on the White House. Along the way, they meet a mysterious African American woman bearing a deep secret. ==Distribution== ''Follow Me Home'' has yet to be picked up by a major distribution company. The film is currently being shown on request, usually at universities and community centers[http://www.nativenetworks.si.edu/Eng/rose/bratt_p_interview.htm Peter Bratt Interview - Native Networks] followed by a discussion facilitated by Native American activist Lakota Harden. ==Awards== Peter Bratt received the Audience Award for Best Feature at the 1996 San Francisco International Film Festival. The film earned the Best Feature Film Audience Award at the 1996 San Francisco International Film Festival. It was also an Official Selection in the 1996 Sundance Film Festival.[http://www.speakoutnow.org/userdata_display.php?modin=50&uid=27 Speak Out : Biography and Booking information] ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.nativenetworks.si.edu/Eng/rose/bratt_p_interview.htm Following Peter: An Interview with Peter Bratt] at Native Networks * [http://www.speakoutnow.org/userdata_display.php?modin=50&uid=27 Follow Me Home: An Exploration of Race and Identity]
at Speak Out Now * [http://www.speakoutnow.org/userdata_display.php?modin=50&uid=60 Lakota Harden: Native American Liberation and the Struggle for Peace and Diversity] at Speak Out Now * {{IMDb title|0119138|Follow Me Home}} [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films set in San Francisco]] [[Category:Films set in the San Francisco Bay Area]] {{indie-film-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Expand French|Symbolisme du coq|date=July 2010}} [[File:Grille_du_Coq_detail.jpg|thumb|Gallic rooster on the garden gate of the [[Palais de l'Elysée]] in Paris, the official residence of the [[President of the French Republic]].]]
The '''Gallic rooster''' ({{lang-fr|le coq gaulois}}, ''the Gallic cock'') is an unofficial [[national symbol]] of [[France]] as a nation, as opposed to [[Marianne]] representing France as a State, and its values: [[French Republic|the Republic]]. The [[rooster]] is also the symbol of the [[Wallonia]] region and the [[French Community of Belgium]].
==France== [[File:Mémorial des soldats et marins de la Charente-Inférieure (16).JPG|thumb|left|Gallic rooster on top of a [[Monuments aux Morts|war memorial]] in [[La Rochelle]]]] During the times of Ancient Rome, [[Suetonius]], in [[The Twelve Caesars]], noticed that, in [[Latin language|Latin]], rooster (''gallus'') and [[Gauls]] (''Gallus'') were [[homonym]]s.<ref name="Drapeau">{{cite web|last1=Collignon|first1=Alain|title=Drapeau wallon|url=http://www.wallonie-en-ligne.net/Encyclopedie/Thematiques/Notices/DrapeauW.htm|publisher=Institut Destrée [The Destree Institute]|accessdate=13 March 2018|location=[[Wallonia]]|language=French|trans-title=Walloon flag|date=6 April 2017}}</ref> However, the association of the Gallic rooster as a national symbol is [[apocrypha]]l, as the rooster was neither regarded as a national personification nor as a sacred animal by the [[Gauls]] in their mythology and because there was no "Gallic nation" at the time, but a loose confederation of Gallic nations instead. But a closer review within that religious scheme indicates that "[[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]]" was often portrayed with the [[rooster|cockerel]],{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} a sacred animal among the [[Continental Celts]].<ref name="Ellis">{{cite book|last1=Ellis|first1=Peter Berresford|authorlink1=Peter Berresford Ellis|title=Dictionary of Celtic Mythology|date=23 June 1994|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0195089615}}</ref> [[Julius Caesar]] in ''[[De Bello Gallico]]'' identified some gods worshipped in [[Gaul]] by using the names of their nearest [[Roman mythology|Roman]] god rather than their Gaulish name, with Caesar saying "[[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]]" was the god most revered in Gaul.<ref>{{Cite wikisource|plaintitle=[[Commentarii de Bello Gallico]]<!-- |language=Latin -->|trans_title=Commentaries on the Gallic War|wslink=Commentaries on the Gallic War/Book 6#17|last=Caesar|first=Julius|authorlink=Julius Caesar|others=Translated from Latin by William Alexander McDevitte and W. S. Bohn (1869)|year=53 BC|volume=Book 6|chapter=Chapter 17|publisher=|location=|page=|pages=|scan=}}</ref> The Irish god [[Lugh|Lug]] identified as ''[[samildánach]]'' led to the widespread identification of Caesar's [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]] as [[Lugus]]{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} and thus also to the sacred cockerel, the Gallic rooster, as an emblem of France.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
Its association with France dates back from the [[Middle Age]] and is due to the play on words in [[Latin language|Latin]] between ''Gallus'', meaning an inhabitant of [[Gaul]], and ''gallus'', meaning [[rooster]], or cockerel. Its use, by the enemies of France, dates to this period, originally a [[pun]] to make fun of the French,<ref name="Drapeau"/> the association between the rooster and the Gauls/French was developed by the kings of France for the strong Christian symbol that the rooster represents: prior to being arrested, Jesus predicted that Peter would deny him three times before the rooster crowed on the following morning. At the rooster's crowing, Peter remembered Jesus's words. Its crowing at the dawning of each new morning made it a symbol of the daily victory of light over darkness and the triumph of good over evil. It is also an emblem of the Christian's attitude of watchfulness and readiness for the sudden return of Christ, the resurrection of the dead, and the final judgment of humankind. That is why, during the [[Renaissance]], the rooster became a symbol of France as a Catholic state and became a popular Christian image on [[weather vane]]s, also known as weathercocks.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}} [[File:Liomer,_Somme,_France.JPG|thumbnail|Gallic rooster atop a [[World War I]] memorial, [[Liomer]] ([[Somme (department)|Somme]]).]] [[File:Logo XV de france.JPG|thumbnail|left|The jersey of the [[France national rugby union team|French national rugby team]], with the traditional Gallic rooster symbol]]
The popularity of the Gallic rooster as a national personification faded away until its resurgence during the [[French Revolution]] (1789). The republican [[historiography]] completely modified the traditional perception of the origins of France. Until then, the royal historiography dated the origins of France back to the baptism of [[Clovis I]] in 496, the "first Christian king of France". The republicans rejected this royalist and Christian origin of the country and trace the origins of France back to the ancient Gaul. Although purely apocryphal, the rooster became the personification of the early inhabitants of France, the Gauls.
The Gallic rooster, colloquially named ''Chanteclair'', had been a national emblem ever since, especially during the [[Third French Republic|Third Republic]]. The rooster was featured on the reverse of French 20-franc gold pieces from 1899 to 1914. After [[World War I]] it was depicted on countless [[war memorials]].
Today, it is often used as a national [[mascot]], particularly in sporting events such as [[Association football|football]] (soccer) and [[rugby football|rugby]]. The [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], hosted by France, adopted a rooster named [[Footix]] as [[mascot]]. The [[France national rugby league team]] are known as the ''Chanteclairs'' referring to the cockerel's song.
The popularity of the symbol extends into business. ''[[Le Coq Sportif]]'' ("The athletic rooster"), is a French manufacturer of sports equipment using a stylized rooster and the colors of the [[French tricolour]] as its logo. Moreover, it is the logo of [[Pathé]], a French-born, now international company of film production and distribution.
Another heraldic animal officially used by the French nation was the [[French Imperial Eagle]], symbol of the [[First French Empire|First]] and [[Second French Empire]] under [[Napoleon I]] and [[Napoleon III]]. {{Clear}}
==Wallonia== [[File:Flag of Wallonia.svg|thumbnail|The [[Flag of Wallonia|Walloon rooster]].]]
In 1913, the Gallic rooster was adopted as the symbol of [[Walloon movement]].{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} It represents a "[[Fighting cocks|bold rooster]]" (''coq hardi''), raising its claws, instead of the "crowing rooster" that is traditionally depicted in France. This symbol, also known as the Walloon rooster, was officially adopted as the symbol of [[Wallonia]] (in 1998) and the [[French Community of Belgium]] (in 1991).
==Cocorico== In France and Wallonia, the [[French language|French]] [[onomatopoeia]] for the rooster [[Rooster#Crowing|crowing sound]], "cocorico" (''cock-a-doodle-doo''), is sometimes used to express national pride.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}}
==See also== *[[Rooster of Barcelos]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscatinline}} *[http://ambafrance-us.org/spip.php?article604 Embassy of France in the United States - additional information] *[http://www.archives.premier-ministre.gouv.fr/villepin/en/acteurs/symbols_of_the_republic_185/the_gallic_rooster_50226.html French Prime Minister's office - additional information] *[http://www.aldaver.com/Images/Wc/wc1998m2.jpg Images of Footix], the cockerel [[mascot]] of the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]]. *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3993495.stm France plucks its bird from peril], from [[BBC]]. A plan to preserve the genetic heritage of the French cockerel.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gallic Rooster}} [[Category:National symbols of France]] [[Category:Heraldic birds]] [[Category:Mythological galliforms]] [[Category:Birds in mythology]] [[Category:Fictional chickens]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Heraldic beasts]] [[de:Hahn (Wappentier)#Der gallische Hahn]]

page.title: General Johnson Saving a Wounded French Officer from the Tomahawk of a North American Indian

revision.comment: /* Description */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: native American → Native American using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Italic title|force=true}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Johnson saving Dieskau.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 240px | title = General Johnson
Saving a Wounded French Officer | artist = [[Benjamin West]] | year = 1764-1768 | medium = [[Oil on canvas]] | city = [[Derby]] | museum = [[Derby Museum and Art Gallery]] }} '''''General Johnson Saving a Wounded French Officer from the Tomahawk of a North American Indian''''' is a painting by [[Benjamin West]], completed between 1764 and 1768. It depicts a scene as observed by a native of Pennsylvania, soon after the actual events shown. It is in the collection of [[Derby Museum and Art Gallery]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.warforempire.org/relive/photo_gallery_Details.aspx?Gallery=7&image=54 |title=Benjamin West Painting |work=The French & Indian War |publisher=warforempire.org |accessdate=2011-08-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327154223/http://www.warforempire.org/relive/photo_gallery_Details.aspx?Gallery=7&image=54 |archivedate=2012-03-27 |df= }}{{Cite web |url = http://www.derby.gov.uk/LeisureCulture/MuseumsGalleries/ArttreasureGeneralJohnson.htm |title = "General Johnson saving a Wounded French Officer from the Tomahawk of a North American Indian" by Benjamin West, PRA |publisher = Derby City Council |accessdate = 2011-08-18 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101223145717/http://www.derby.gov.uk/LeisureCulture/MuseumsGalleries/ArttreasureGeneralJohnson.htm |archivedate = 2010-12-23 |df = }} == Description == The painting is important as it is a contemporary view showing all three powers involved during the 1750s in the [[French and Indian War]] (which could be called more comprehensively "the [[United Kingdom|British]], [[France|French]] and [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indian]] War"{{Cite news | author=Joel Achenbach | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/gog/exhibits/clash-of-empires-the-british-french-and-indian-war-1754-1763,1093313/critic-review.html#reviewNum1 | title=Clash of Empires: The British, French and Indian War, 1754-1763 | newspaper=The Washington Post | page=C01 | date=2006-12-16 | accessdate=2011-08-14}}). It depicts Major General [[Sir William Johnson, 1st Baronet|Sir William Johnson]] preventing a North American native warrior from [[scalping|taking the scalp]] of [[Jean Erdman, Baron Dieskau|Baron Dieskau]],Stephanie Pratt, [https://books.google.com/books?id=k2QEI_GiIsUC&pg=PA76&dq=General+Johnson+saving+a+Wounded+French+Officer+from+the+Tomahawk+of+a+North+American+Indian&hl=fr&ei=ZhIbTsSIOYb1-gbyo-XXBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=General%20Johnson%20saving%20a%20Wounded%20French%20Officer%20from%20the%20Tomahawk%20of%20a%20North%20American%20Indian&f=false ''American Indians in British Art, 1700-1840''], University of Oklahoma Press, 2005, 240 p. ({{ISBN|978-0806136578}}), p. 75-76. a wounded and defeated French soldier lying on the ground. West was an early American painter. He claimed to have been first taught how to make paint by a Native American childhood friend who demonstrated how paint could be made by mixing clay with [[Bear's grease|bear grease]].[http://www.wgbh.org/articles/Music-and-Art--West-and-Antes-1679 Music and Art], Catherine Fuller, WGBH, retrieved 28 June 2014 This painting has fine detail on the native figure, whose plucked scalp and tattoos are shown in more detail than the Europeans' uniforms. West is known to have had a collection of North American artefacts which he used in his paintings.{{Cite book | last=Pratt | first=Stephanie | title=American Indians in British art, 1700-1840 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k2QEI_GiIsUC&pg=PA169&dq=benjamin+west+native+american+bear&hl=en&ei=BJQhTsrHB4-38QOYv5mtAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFwQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=general%20johnson&f=false | accessdate=2011-08-18 | year=2005 | publisher=Univ of Oklahoma Pr | isbn=978-0-8061-3657-8 | pages=85, 198}} Benjamin West probably began this painting soon after his arrival in London, in 1763, when West returned from [[Italy]], where he spent three years. Following ''The Indian Family'', a painting of about 1761, this one demonstrates the same willingness to show "the proper dress and accoutrement".{{Cite book | last=Pratt | first=Stephanie | title=American Indians in British art, 1700-1840 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k2QEI_GiIsUC&pg=PA76&dq=General+Johnson+saving+a+Wounded+French+Officer+from+the+Tomahawk+of+a+North+American+Indian&hl=fr&ei=ZhIbTsSIOYb1-gbyo-XXBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=General%20Johnson%20saving%20a%20Wounded%20French%20Officer%20from%20the%20Tomahawk%20of%20a%20North%20American%20Indian&f=false | accessdate=2011-08-18 | year=2005 | publisher=Univ of Oklahoma Pr | isbn=978-0-8061-3657-8 | pages=75–76, 240}} Thus it provides us with one of two known contemporary pictures of the British [[Light infantry|Light Infantrymen]] for the French and Indian War period.{{Cite web | url=http://schrothscompany.com/document_folder/46th_Uniforms.pdf | title=Uniforms of the 46th Regiment of Foot | page=2 | format=PDF | publisher=Schroth's New York Company | accessdate=2011-08-18}} Whereas in the Italian painting, accuracy and authenticity were intended to give a generic representation of the Indian life, the new one employed them to make a report of a recent historical event. Although the subject matter and some "physical and symbolic details" could be found more closely corresponding to the [[Battle of Fort Niagara]] (1759),Pierre Pouchot, Michael Cardy (translation) and Brian Leigh Dunnigan (edition and notes), ''Memoirs on the Late War in North America Between France & England'' ({{fr icon}} ''Mémoires sur la dernière guerre de l'Amérique septentrionale entre la France et l'Angleterre'', Switzerland, Yverdon, 1781), Youngstown (N.Y.), Old Fort Niagara Association, 1994, 568 p. ({{ISBN|9780941967143}}), p. 232 ([https://books.google.com/books?id=MvcQAQAAMAAJ&q=West+%22general+Johnson+saving%22+Dieskau&dq=West+%22general+Johnson+saving%22+Dieskau&hl=fr&ei=ZfIaTo3LB8aj8QPtk9SFCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw note]). the painting is usually related to an incident that occurred during the campaign of 1755 around [[Lake George (New York)|Lake George]], when the French commanded by [[Jean Erdman, Baron Dieskau|Baron Dieskau]], with their Indian allies, were opposed by a mixed troop of [[Mohawk nation|Mohawk]] and [[New England]] [[militia]], led by Johnson. After having repulsed an attack against their camp, the British and their auxiliaries took over. Dieskau, wounded three times, had his life saved by Johnson, who protected him from the Mohawks wanting revenge for their killed kinsmen. He actually survived and was taken as a prisoner to [[New York City|New York]], then to London, and then to [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] for treatment of a still unhealed wound. At the end of the [[Seven Years' War]] in 1763, he was repatriated to France, where he died in 1767.{{Cite DCB |first=James R. |last=Turnbull |volume=3 |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/dieskau_jean_armand_3E.html |title=Dieskau, Jean-Armand, baron de Dieskau |accessdate=2011-08-18}} West returned to the American war in his ''[[The Death of General Wolfe]]'', exhibited in 1771, a much larger work that made his reputation, though causing controversy through its use of contemporary costume. == Historical context == [[File:Benjamin West 005.jpg|thumb|300px|left|West's ''[[The Death of General Wolfe]],'' 1770]] By showing Johnson restraining the aggressive actions of an auxiliary, the painting promotes "civilized" standards of honor and laws of war, as opposed to the ferocity of "savages". It refers to the concerns and debates that the employment of Indian allies aroused among [[Europe]]ans, throughout the conflicts in [[North America]]. Johnson's act of humanity contrasts against Johnson's reputation which has included him being described as a "White Savage" for his general attitude.[[Fintan O'Toole|O'Toole, Fintan]]. ''White Savage: William Johnson and the Invention of America''. New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 2005. {{ISBN|0-374-28128-9}} At the beginning of the French and Indian War, young [[George Washington]] is said to have let Indian chief Tanaghrisson seal their fresh alliance by smashing the skull of [[Joseph Coulon de Jumonville]], a wounded French officer they just took as prisoner, then washing his hands in the man's brain. The [[Battle of Jumonville Glen|Jumonville affair]] caused a scandal in Europe, where it accelerated the expansion of the Seven Years' War. The same questions persisted during the [[American Revolutionary War|War of Independence of the United States]]. In 1777, both Houses of [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|British Parliament]] debated over the use of Indian auxiliaries. [[William Pitt, 1st Earl of Chatham|William Pitt]]'s speech in the [[House of Lords]] (November 20), denouncing acts of violence perpetrated against "innocents" and the practice of [[cannibalism]], is indicative of reluctances that appear to have been widely shared. == Further reading == *Jonathon Conlin - Benjamin West's General Johnson and Representations of British Imperial Identity, 1759–1770. An Empire of Mercy?{{cite journal|last=Conlin|first=Jonathon|title=Benjamin West's General Johnson and Representations of British Imperial Identity, 1759–1770. An Empire of Mercy?|journal=Journal for Eighteenth-Century Studies|year=2004|volume=27|issue=1|pages=37–59|doi=10.1111/j.1754-0208.2004.tb00277.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1754-0208.2004.tb00277.x/abstract|accessdate=4 February 2012}} *Stephen Mark Caffey and Art History, The University of Texas at Austin - An Heroics of Empire: Benjamin West and Anglophone History Painting 1764--1774 {{cite book|first1=Stephen Mark|last1=Caffey|title= An Heroics of Empire: Benjamin West and Anglophone History Painting 1764--1774|date=2008|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nQKAAkf1g-wC&pg=PA33#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=University of Texas at Austin|ISBN=978-0-549-77858-5|first2=The University of Texas at Austin.|last2=Art History|pages=33-42|chapter=Chapter 1 - West's First Heroics of History Painting|access-date=March 14, 2017}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Derby Museum}} [[Category:Collections of Derby Museum and Art Gallery]] [[Category:War paintings]] [[Category:British paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Benjamin West]] [[Category:French and Indian War]] [[Category:1768 paintings]]

revision.text:
[[File:Songhuizong4.jpg|300px|thumb|''Golden Pheasant and Cotton Rose Flowers with Butterflies'' (11th century) by [[Emperor Huizong of Song]]]]
'''''Gongbi''''' ({{Zh|t=工筆|s=工笔|p=gōng bǐ|w=kung-pi}}) is a careful [[Realism (arts)|realist]] technique in [[Chinese painting]], the opposite of the interpretive and freely expressive ''[[Xieyi (painting)|xieyi]]'' (寫意 'sketching thoughts') style.
The name is from the Chinese ''gong jin'' meaning 'tidy' (meticulous brush craftsmanship). The ''gongbi'' technique uses highly detailed brushstrokes that delimits details very precisely and without independent or expressive variation.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Gongbi Painting - Chinese Traditional Painting with Meticulous Detail - China culture Qiu Ying, Shen Quan|url = http://arts.cultural-china.com/en/62Arts2192.html|website = arts.cultural-china.com|access-date = 2016-02-04|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090409090447/http://arts.cultural-china.com/en/62Arts2192.html|archivedate = 2009-04-09|df = }}</ref> It is often highly colored and usually depicts figural or narrative subjects.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = gongbi {{!}} Chinese painting|url = http://www.britannica.com/art/gongbi|website = Encyclopædia Britannica|access-date = 2016-02-04}}</ref> One of the better known Gongbi works is the Song Dynasty Scroll, 17 feet long and includes intricate details that most don’t pick up. It is one of many popular tourist attractions in China today, as it is updated regularly to try and show what modern China looks like compared to when it was created during the Song Dynasty.<ref>{{cite web |title=Two Versions of the Scroll |url=http://afe.easia.columbia.edu/songdynasty-module/intro-two-versions.html |website=The Song Dynasty in China: China in 1000 CE |publisher=Columbia University |accessdate=17 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
The term related to ''gongbi'', ''jiehua'' (or "boundary painting"), refers to the accurate depiction of [[architectural]] forms aided by the ruler.<ref name=":0" />
==History== The ''gongbi'' style had its beginnings approximately 2000 years ago during the [[Han dynasty]] (206 BC – 220 AD) when Han's political stability and its prosperity favored the advancement of the arts. These paintings peaked out between the [[Tang dynasty|Tang]] and [[Song dynasty|Song]] dynasties (7th to 13th centuries) when these refined paintings were endorsed and collected by the royal families of China. To perfect this style the ''gongbi'' artists must totally commit themselves to these techniques. Only the wealthy could afford such artists. This style of art was accomplished in secret in royal palaces and private homes. Gongbi is one of the oldest Chinese painting techniques that feature narratives or high authority figures in them.
==Tools== When using brushes to paint gongbi, there are specific types for contouring and colouring. There are four types of brushes for [[contour drawing|contouring]]; Hong Mao (red hairs), are used to draw thick strokes mainly for [[landscape]] and background visuals. Yi Wen is used for longer lines to paint clothing, for example. Ye Jing brushes are used to contour flowers and bedsheets. Xie Zhua is the finest contour brush used to paint strokes of dragonflies and specific detail in the painting. There are three sizes of brushes used to colour the surface of the painting: Da Bai Yun (large white cloud), Zhong Bai Yun (average white cloud) and Xiao Bai Yun (small white cloud). Rough drafts are usually drawn on [[rice paper]]. If there is only one draft, a special type of paper called [[Xuan paper]] is used. The soft paper is able to absorb water well, best used for [[Chinese painting]] and [[calligraphy]].<ref name=":1">http://www.chine-culture.com/en/chinese-painting/chinese-painting-gongbi.php; retrieved on 2014-04-3</ref> Silk can also be used, which is sized as well.
==Process of the craft== ''Gongbi'' requires drawing with fine lines first to represent the exaggerated likenesses of the objects, and then adds washes of ink and color layer by layer, so as to approach the perfection of exquisiteness and fine art. The practice of Gongbi is specifically on rice paper when sketching out the design and layout of the drawing. Typically, pencil is used before beginning the second draft with the tipped brushes. The variation and detail in strokes are important especially when layering each wash of ink on top of each other. There are upward and downward strokes used that emphasize detailed pictures such as facial features and insects.<ref name=":1" /> After hundreds of years, a technique was developed for all gongbi artists as a system. Lines are used first to contour the figure and determine the fine outlines of the painting. Modest colors are added to the painting that add onto a sense of nature; flamboyant colors are used when the content of the painting has accentuated lines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chinaculture.org/classics/2012-02/10/content_429449_2.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407095336/http://www.chinaculture.org/classics/2012-02/10/content_429449_2.htm |archivedate=2014-04-07 |df= }} retrieved on 2014-04-3</ref>
==''Gongbi'' painters== Listed chronologically: * [[Yan Liben]] (c. 600–673) * [[Zhang Xuan]] (713–755) * [[Zhou Fang (Tang dynasty)|Zhou Fang]] (c. 730–800) * [[Gu Hongzhong]] (937–975) * [[Emperor Huizong of Song]] (1082–1135) * [[Tang Yin]] (1470–1524) * [[Qiu Ying]] (1494–1552) * [[Chen Hongshou]] (1598–1652)
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Chinese painting]] [[Category:Painting techniques]]

{{no footnotes|date=August 2011}}
'''Gorm Henrik Rasmussen''' (born 1955) is a Danish poet who wrote the first biography about the guitarist and singer-songwriter [[Nick Drake]], ''Pink Moon'' (1986). The book is based upon interviews Gorm Henrik Rasmussen made with Nick Drake's parents, Rodney and [[Molly Drake]], in their home in [[Tanworth-in-Arden]], [[Warwickshire]], England, in 1979 and 1980. ''[http://rocket88books.com/2012/01/27/pink-moon/ Pink Moon]'' was re-written and translated into English in 2009. In 2012, it became the launch title for [http://rocket88books.com/ Rocket 88], a new music book imprint of [http://www.essentialworks.co.uk/ Essential Works]. A Spanish version has also appeared in 2012.
Gorm Henrik Rasmussen is known in Denmark for a number of books about eccentrics and strange places in the [[northern part of Jutland]] where he was born and raised. He has received several literary awards from [[The Danish Arts Foundation]] and The Danish Arts Council.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}} *[[Trevor Dann|Dann, Trevor]]: ''Darker than the Deepest Sea'', DaCapo Press: London, 2006: 166, 207-8 *[[Gabrielle Drake|Drake, Gabrielle]] & Cally Callomon: ''Remembered for a While'', John Murray: London, 2014, p. 419-422.
== External links == * [http://www.litteraturpriser.dk/aut/RG.htm#RGormHenrikRasmussen List of awards from litteraturpriser.dk] * [http://www.algonet.se/~iguana/DRAKE/NDunrel.html The Nick Drake Files] * [http://www.tannforsen.com/nickdrake/media.asp?intId=36 nickdrake.net] * [http://rocket88books.com/2012/01/27/pink-moon ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake'' published by Rocket 88, a music book imprint of Essential Works] * [http://rocket88books.com/2012/02/29/mojo-magazine-review-of-pink-moon-a-story-about-nick-drake Review in Mojo of ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake''] * [http://reviews.libraryjournal.com/2012/03/collection-development/books-for-dudes/books-for-dudes Review in Library Journal of ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake''] * [http://gaffa.dk/anmeldelse/58029 Review in Gaffa of ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake'']
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rasmussen, Gorm Henrik}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Danish male writers]] [[Category:Arts in Denmark|Literature]] [[Category:Danish biographers]] [[Category:Male biographers]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Living people]]

[[File:Ica stones3.JPG|thumb|right|300px|An Ica stone allegedly depicting dinosaurs.]]
The '''Ica stones''' are a collection of [[andesite]] stones found in [[Ica Province]], [[Peru]] that bear a variety of diagrams. Some of them supposedly have depictions of [[dinosaur]]s, and what is alleged to be advanced [[technology]]. These are recognised as modern curiosities or [[hoax]]es.
From the 1960s Javier Cabrera Darquea collected and popularized the stones, obtaining many of them from a farmer named Basilio Uschuya. Uschuya, after claiming them to be real ancient artifacts, admitted to creating the carvings he had sold and said he produced a [[patina]] by baking the stone in cow dung.
==Description== The stones are composed of [[andesite]]. They vary in size from 3x2.5x1.5 cm to 40 cm.<ref name=Pezzia1968a/> As a result of weathering, they have developed a thin [[patina]]. It consists of a [[weathering rind]] in which weathering has turned some of the [[feldspar]] into [[clay]], resulting in a softer material, rated 3 to 4 on the [[Mohs scale of mineral hardness]], which can be scratched.<ref name=Pezzia1968a/>
They are shallowly [[engraving|engraved]] with a variety of images, some directly incised, others by removing the background, leaving the image in [[relief]]. The images vary from simple pictures on one side of a pebble, up to designs of great complexity. Some of the designs are in styles which can be recognized as belonging to the [[Paracas culture|Paracas]], [[Nazca culture|Nazca]], [[Tiwanaku]], or [[Inca]] cultures.<ref name=Pezzia1968a/>
Some of the images are of flowers, fish, or living animals of various sorts.<ref name=Pezzia1968a/> Others appear to depict scenes<ref name = Skepdic>{{cite book |author=Carroll, Robert T. |authorlink=Robert Todd Carroll |title=[[The Skeptic's Dictionary]]: a collection of strange beliefs, amusing deceptions, and dangerous delusions |publisher=Wiley |location=New York |year=2003 |pages= [https://books.google.com/books?id=6FPqDFx40vYC&pg=PA169#v=onepage&q=&f=false 169–71]|isbn=0-471-27242-6 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}, also online at [http://www.skepdic.com/icastones.html skepdic]</ref><ref name=Fortean>{{cite journal |last=Coppens |first=P |title=Jurassic library - The Ica Stones |journal=[[Fortean Times]] |date=October 2001 |url=http://www.forteantimes.com/features/articles/259/jurassic_library_the_ica_stones.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827173630/http://forteantimes.com/features/articles/259/jurassic_library_the_ica_stones.html |archivedate=2008-08-27 |df= }}</ref> which would be anachronistic in [[Pre-Columbian era|pre-Columbian]] art, such as knowledge of dinosaurs, advanced medical works and maps.<ref name="Carroll2011">{{cite book|last=Carroll|first=Robert|title=The Skeptic's Dictionary: A Collection of Strange Beliefs, Amusing Deceptions, and Dangerous Delusions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6FPqDFx40vYC|accessdate=8 December 2013|date=2011-01-11|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118045633}}</ref>
==Background== Archaeological remains show evidence of Peruvian cultures going back for several thousand years. At some later stages, the whole of modern Peru was united into a single political and cultural unit, culminating in the [[Inca Empire]], followed by the [[Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire|Spanish conquest]]. At other stages, areas such as the [[Ica Valley]], a habitable region separated from others by desert, developed a distinctive culture of its own.<ref name=Lanning>{{cite book|title = Peru before the Incas| first=Edward P.| last=Lanning| publisher=Prentice-Hall| year=1967}}</ref>
Excavations in [[Ica Province]] were carried out in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries by scholars such as [[Max Uhle]], [[Julio C. Tello]], [[Alfred L. Kroeber]], [[William Duncan Strong]] and [[John Howland Rowe]]. None of them reported the discovery of carved andesite stones. Nevertheless, carved stones which had been looted by ''huaqueros'', grave robbers, began to be offered for sale to tourists and amateur collectors.<ref name=Pezzia1968a>Pezzia Assereto, A (1968) Ica y el Perú Precolombino. Tomo I. Arqueología de la provincia de Ica. Empresa Editora Liberia, Ojeda, Venezuela. 295 pp.</ref>
One of these collectors was Santiago Agurto Calvo, an architect by profession, who was [[Rector (academia)|Rector]] of the [[National University of Engineering]] in [[Lima]]. He organised searches in ancient cemeteries, and in August 1966 found such a stone in the Toma Luz sector, Callango district, in [[Ica Valley]]. The context corresponded to the [[Tiwanaku]] culture. He reported his discovery to the Regional Museum in [[Ica city]], and was accompanied on further expeditions by its curator, the archaeologist Alejandro Pezzia Assereto.<ref name=Pezzia1968a/> In September 1966 in Uhle Hill cemetery, De la Banda sector, [[Ocucaje District]], they found, for the first time, an engraved stone with certain provenance in a tomb of the [[Paracas culture]]. This stone was a fairly flat and irregular in shape, approximately 7 x 6 x 2 cm in size. On it was carved a design which might be abstract, or could be taken as a flower with eight petals.<ref name=Pezzia1968a/> Agurto published the discovery in a Lima newspaper.<ref>Santiago Agurto Calvo. "Las Piedras Magicas de Ocucaje". ''El Comercio''. Lima, 11 December 1966</ref>
Pezzia continued to search. In the ''San Evaristo'' cemetery in Toma Luz, he found a carved stone of similar size to the previous one, with a realistic image of a fish. The context dated the tomb to the [[Middle Horizon]] (600-1000 A.D.). In a grave not far away in the same cemetery, he found a stone with the fairly realistic design of a [[llama]], in a context typical of the Ica culture. In 1968, Pezzia published his findings, including drawings and descriptions.<ref name=Pezzia1968a/>
==Popularization by Cabrera== [[File:Ica stones1.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A collection of Ica stones surrounding a portrait of Javier Cabrera]]
Meanwhile, in 1966, Peruvian physician Javier Cabrera Darquea was presented with a stone that had a carved picture of a fish, which Cabrera believed to be of an extinct species.<ref>{{cite book |title= The Message of the Stones |last= Cabrera |first= Javier |location= Ica, Peru |url= http://members.cox.net/icastones/02a-book-chapter-1.htm |accessdate= 10 May 2012 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://archive.is/20111202175320/http://members.cox.net/icastones/02a-book-chapter-1.htm |archivedate= 2 December 2011 |df= }}</ref> Cabrera's father had begun a collection of similar stones in the 1930s, and based on his interest in Peruvian prehistory, Cabrera began collecting more. He initially purchased more than 300 from two brothers, Carlos and Pablo Soldi, who also collected pre-[[Inca Empire|Incan]] artifacts, who claimed they had unsuccessfully attempted to interest [[Archaeology|archaeologists]] in them. Cabrera later found another source of the stones, a farmer named Basilio Uschuya, who sold him thousands more. Cabrera's collection burgeoned, reaching more than 11,000 stones in the 1970s.<ref name = Fortean/> Cabrera published a book, ''The Message of the Engraved Stones of Ica'' on the subject, discussing his theories of the origins and meaning of the stones. In this he argued that the stones show "that man is at least 405 million years old" and for what he calls ''gliptolithic'' man, humans from another planet, and that "Through the transplantation of cognitive codes to highly intelligent primates, the men from outer space created new men on earth." <ref>{{cite book|last=Cabrera|first=Javier|title=The message of the engraved stones of Ica|year=2000|url=http://openlibrary.org/books/OL16716029M/The_message_of_the_engraved_stones_of_Ica}}</ref> The Ica stones achieved greater popular interest when Cabrera abandoned his medical career and opened a museum to feature several thousand of the stones in 1996.<ref name = Skepdic/>
In 1973, during an interview with [[Erich von Däniken]], Uschuya stated he had faked the stones that he had sold.<ref name = Fortean/> In 1975 Uschuya and another farmer named Irma Gutierrez de Aparcana confirmed that they had forged the stones they gave to Cabrera by copying the images from comic books, text books and magazines.<ref name = Skepdic/> Later, Uschuya recanted the forging story during an interview with a German journalist, saying that he had claimed they were a hoax to avoid imprisonment for selling [[Artifact (archaeology)|archaeological artifacts]]. In 1977, during the [[BBC]] documentary ''Pathway to the Gods'', Uschuya produced an Ica stone with a dentist's drill and claimed to have produced a fake patina by baking the stone in cow dung.<ref name = Fortean/> That same year, another BBC documentary was released with a skeptical analysis of Cabrera's stones, and the new-found attention to the phenomenon prompted Peruvian authorities to arrest Uschuya, as Peruvian law prohibits the sale of archaeological discoveries. Uschuya recanted his claim that he had found them and instead admitted they were [[hoax]]es, saying "Making these stones is easier than farming the land." He engraved the stones using images in books and magazines as examples and knives, chisels and a dental drill.<ref name=" Feder 2010a">[[Kenneth L. Feder]], ''Encyclopedia of Dubious Archaeology: From Atlantis To The Walam Olum'', pages 143 (Greenwood, 2010). {{ISBN|978-0-313-37919-2}}</ref> He also said that he had not made all the stones. He was not punished, and continued to sell similar stones to tourists as trinkets.<ref name = Fortean/> The stones continued to be made and carved by other artists as forgeries of the original forgeries.<ref name = Skepdic/>
==Impact== Except in the rare cases that [[provenance]] is known, there is no reliable way of dating the stones.<ref name = Fortean/> Thus, a stone of uncertain origin can never be used to establish a conclusion which would otherwise be considered unlikely. The stones have been used by some [[Creationism|creationists]] to claim that humans lived in proximity with dinosaurs, which contradicts evidence that the [[extinction of dinosaurs]] predates mankind by approximately 66 million years.<ref>{{cite web|title=What really happened when the dino killer asteroid struck?|url=http://www.bbc.com/earth/story/20160415-what-really-happened-when-the-dino-killer-asteroid-struck|website=BBC.com|publisher=BBC|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> At least one official creationist source has rejected their use as an argument for creationism.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ica Stones Bad Arguments|url=https://creation.com/ica-stones-bad-arguments|website=creation.com|publisher=Creation Ministries International|accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref> Believers in [[ancient astronauts]] have also attempted to use the stones as evidence of a lost, advanced civilization brought to man from other planets<ref name = Fortean/> and mytho-historians have claimed them as evidence that ancient myths are accurate histories, neither of which is a position supported in the scientific or academic communities.<ref name = Skepdic/>
In his ''Encyclopedia of Dubious Archaeology: From Atlantis To The [[Walam Olum]]'', archaeologist [[Ken Feder]] commented "The Ica Stones are not the most sophisticated of the archaeological hoaxes discussed in this book, but they certainly rank up there as the most preposterous."<ref name=" Feder 2010a"/>
==See also== * [[Out-of-place artifact]] * [[Acámbaro figures]] * [[Rock art]]
==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Ica stones}} *[http://www.omniology.com/IcaPeruBurialStones3.jpg Images of the Ica stones] *[http://www.piedrasdeica.es Theory post-Cabrera - articles on the Ica Stones, the Global Elite, the Pleiadians, etc.] *[http://pseudoarchaeology.org/b03-ross.html Ica stones] at the Pseudoarcheology Research Archive
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ica Stones}} [[Category:20th-century hoaxes]] [[Category:Archaeological forgeries]] [[Category:Hoaxes in Peru]] [[Category:Out-of-place artifacts]] [[Category:Peruvian art]] [[Category:Pseudoarchaeology]] [[Category:Pseudohistory]]

revision.text:
'''James Thomas Hooper''' (1 September 1897 – 9 February 1971) was a British collector of ethnographic artifacts of the Inuit, Native American, Oceanic and African peoples.
Hooper was born in North Wraxall-Wiltshire<ref>{{Cite web | title = Hooper, James Thomas | work = Danster Who's Who in African Art | url = http://www.danster-research.com/bin/who/htmlwho.cgi?search=2016213~01 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}} {{Dead link|date=November 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> in 1897 and began collecting in 1912 when his father gave him a native spear.<ref>{{Cite web | title = TOTEM MUSEUM video newsreel film |publisher = British Pathe | url = http://www.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=734 | accessdate = 22 July 2010}}</ref> He became an employee of the Thames Conservancy Board<ref>{{Cite web|last=Hall |first=Michael |title=BOOK OF THE YEAR |work=Apollo Magazine |date=3 December 2007 |url=http://www.apollo-magazine.com/features/384731/book-of-the-year.thtml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121101071045/http://www.apollo-magazine.com/features/384731/book-of-the-year.thtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 1 November 2012 |accessdate=22 July 2010 |df= }}</ref> but collecting was his obsession. He scoured flea markets and small antique shops in rural England for items of interest as well as purchasing from auction houses, private museums and house sales. He also organised exchanges with other dealers and collectors such as [[William Ockelford Oldman]] and [[Kenneth Athol Webster]].
At the height of his collecting in the 1950s, he was one of the top four collectors of pacific ethnographic material in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Tatua (belt) | work = Collections Online |publisher = Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa | url = http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/ObjectDetails.aspx?oid=53958 | accessdate = 21 July 2010}}</ref> Others included [[Kenneth Athol Webster]] and [[William Ockelford Oldman]]. Hooper's interest in collecting this material was ethnological rather than aesthetic. Like Oldman, Hooper never left Great Britain to visit the cultures that created the material he enjoyed.
After his retirement, Hooper opened the Totems Museum in Arundel, Sussex, United Kingdom in a two-story building on the High Street. He ran this museum between 1957 and 1963. The ground-floor rooms were packed full of his ethnographic collection while he and his grandson, Steven Hooper, lived in the rooms above.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Hooper | first = Steven | title = STEVEN HOOPER | work = Art and Divinity in Polynesia, 1760-1860 | url = http://www.quaibranly.fr/uploads/tx_gayafeespacepresse/MQB-DP-Polynesie-arts-divinites-1760-1860-EN.pdf | accessdate = 22 July 2010}}</ref> The British Pathe newsreel film dated 9 December 1957 follows a couple visiting the Totems Museum. While the film gives little information when describing the treasures of the museum, close attention to the background and general shots of the interior of the museum give an excellent insight into the size, diversity and quality of Hooper's collection.<ref>{{Cite web | title = TOTEM MUSEUM video newsreel film |publisher = British Pathe | url = http://www.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=734 | accessdate = 22 July 2010}}</ref>
In 1954, he co-authored the publication ''The Art of Primitive Peoples'' with Cottie Arthur Burland. In it, Hooper concentrates on the [[art of Polynesia]], Melanesia, North Coast of America, Eskimo, West Africa and the Congo. His text is illustrated with 116 photographs of items from his collection taken by R.H. Bomback.<ref>{{Cite web | title = The art of primitive peoples / by J.T. Hooper and C.A. Burland ; with 116 photographs of specimens from the Hooper collection by R.H. Bomback | work = National Library of Australia Catalogue | publisher = National Library of Australia | url = http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1014613 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref> Soon after the opening of the Totems Museum, he published a guide booklet titled ''The Totems Museum, High Street, Arundel, Sussex : exhibiting the Hooper Collection of primitive art from Africa, the Pacific islands, New Zealand and the Americas''.<ref>{{Cite web | title = The Totems Museum, High Street, Arundel, Sussex : exhibiting the Hooper Collection of primitive art from Africa, the Pacific islands, New Zealand and the Americas / by J.T. Hooper; 11 pages with illustrations | work = National Library of Australia Catalogue | publisher = National Library of Australia | url = http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1873065 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref> This was also illustrated. The Hooper Collection was also documented through photography as Hooper allowed visitors and researchers to photograph his collections.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Shuster | first = Carl | title = Photograph of Ivory Bead Necklace from J. T. Hooper Collection | work = DOE Oceania: Fiji: Gen/Misc 04963400 | publisher = National Anthropological Archives, Smithsonian Institution | url = http://siris-archives.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=12797R3C72B56.13880&profile=all&uri=link=3100006~!48509~!3100001~!3100002&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=2&source=~!siarchives&term=Totems+Museum&index= | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | last = Shuster | first = Carl | title = Photograph of Ivory Bead Necklace from J. T. Hooper Collection | work = DDOE Oceania: Fiji: Gen/Misc 04964200 | publisher = National Anthropological Archives, Smithsonian Institution | url = http://siris-archives.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=12J99L8690131.37784&profile=all&uri=link=3100006~!48520~!3100001~!3100002&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=2&source=~!siarchives&term=the+Totems+Museum&index=NAMEP | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref> Photographs of works from his collection can be found in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Object in photograph in collection of Totems Museum, Arundel, Sussex, England | work = Collection Database | publisher = The Metropolitan Museum of Art | url = http://www.metmuseum.org/works_of_art/collection_database/all/listview.aspx?page=1&sort=0&sortdir=asc&keyword=%22Totems%20Museum%22&fp=1&dd1=0&dd2=0&vw=1 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref>
Hooper's collection continued to be documented after his death in 1971. His collection was the subject of a book by his grandson Steven Phelps – now known as Steven Hooper. ''Art and Artifacts of the Pacific, Africa and the Americas: The James Hooper Collection'' was published in 1976 and featured 250 illustrations. Soon after this book was published, parts of the collection began to be auctioned by Christie's. Between 1976 and 1982 there were at least six auctions of material from the James Hooper Collection. The auctions included ''African Art from the James Hooper Collection'' held on 14 July 1976 at Christie's London,<ref>{{Cite book | title = African Art from the James Hooper Collection | publisher = Christie's | date = 14 July 1976 | location = London | pages = | isbn = }}</ref> ''American Indian Art from the James Hooper Collection'' held on 9 Nov 1976 at Christie's London,<ref>{{Cite book | title = American Indian Art from the James Hooper Collection | publisher = Christie's | date = 9 Nov 1976 | location = London | pages = , 207 lots auctioned, 207 lots illustrated | isbn = }}</ref> ''Hawaiian and Maori Art from the James Hooper Collection'' held on 21 June 1977 at Christie's London,<ref>{{Cite book | title = Hawaiian and Maori Art from the James Hooper Collection | publisher = Christie's | date = 21 June 1977 | location = London | pages = 61, 203 lots auctioned, 196 lots illustrated | isbn = }}</ref> ''Melanesian and Polynesian Art from the James Hooper Collection'' held on 19 June 1979 at Christie's London,<ref>{{Cite book | title = Melanesian and Polynesian Art from the James Hooper Collection | publisher = Christie's | date = 19 June 1979 | location = London | pages = 63, 198 lots auctioned, 198 lots illustrated | isbn = }}</ref> ''Oceanic Art From the James Hooper Collection'' held on 17 June 1980 at Christie's London.<ref>{{Cite book | title = Oceanic Art From the James Hooper Collection | publisher = Christie's | date = 17 June 1980 | location = London | pages = 56, 160 lots auctioned, 151 lots illustrated | isbn = }}</ref> and ''Important Tribal Art'' held on 7 July 1982 at Christie's London.<ref>{{Cite book | title = Important Tribal Art from the properties of ... James T. Hooper | publisher = Christie's | date = 7 July 1982 | location = London | pages = 63, 158 lots auctioned | isbn = }}</ref>
Museums around the world now own items from the James Hooper collection, either as a result of successful bidding at these auctions or through the generosity of other successful bidders. Items from his collection can be found in the collections of *the [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Hooper, James | work = Collections Online |publisher = Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa | url = http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/Party.aspx?irn=15887 | accessdate = 21 July 2010}}</ref> *the [[British Museum]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Drum (pahu hula) |publisher = British Museum | url = https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aoa/d/drum_pahu_hula.aspx | accessdate = 22 July 2010}}</ref> *the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Forehead Ornament (Kapkap) | work = African and Oceanic Art from the Barbier-Mueller Museum, Geneva: A Legacy of Collecting | publisher = The Metropolitan Museum of Art | url = http://www.metmuseum.org/special/barbier_mueller/view_1.asp?item=26 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | title = Works associated with James Hooper | work = The Metropolitan Museum of Art Collections Database | publisher = The Metropolitan Museum of Art | url = http://www.metmuseum.org/works_of_art/collection_database/all/listview.aspx?page=1&sort=0&sortdir=asc&keyword=%22James%20Hooper%22&fp=1&dd1=0&dd2=0&vw=1 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | title = Fan handle | work = African and Oceanic Art from the Barbier-Mueller Museum, Geneva: A Legacy of Collecting | publisher = The Metropolitan Museum of Art | url = http://www.metmuseum.org/special/barbier_mueller/view_1.asp?item=31 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref> *the [[Canadian Museum of Civilization]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = carved wooden food bowl | work = Hosting the Feast | publisher = Canadian Museum of Civilisation | url = http://www.civilization.ca/cmc/exhibitions/aborig/haida/haahf04e.shtml | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref> *the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Collections Search Results | work = Collections | publisher = Museum of Fine Arts, Boston | url = http://www.mfa.org/collections/search_art.asp?coll_accession=&coll_name=&coll_artist=&coll_medium=&coll_culture=&coll_classification=&coll_credit=&coll_provenance=%22James+Hooper%22&coll_keywords=&coll_sort=2&coll_sort_order=0&submit=Search | accessdate = 24 July 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

{{Infobox Painting | image_file=File:Rossetti, Dante Gabriel - La Ghirlandata - 1871-1874.jpg | image_size =200px | title=La Ghirlandata | artist=[[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] | year=1873 | type=? | dimensions = ? | city=[[London]] | museum=[[Guildhall Art Gallery]] }}'''''La Ghirlandata''''' ''("The Garlanded Woman")'' is an 1873 painting by English painter and poet [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]].<ref name="British Library - La Ghirlandata by Dante Gabriel Rossetti">{{cite web|url=https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/la-ghirlandata-by-dante-gabriel-rossetti|title=La Ghirlandata by Dante Gabriel Rossetti|publisher=[[British Library]]|accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> It is currently in the collection of the [[Guildhall Art Gallery]] in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="Culture24 - 23 January 2015 - Guildhall Art Gallery rehang breathes life into a major Victorian art collection">{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/art/painting-and-drawing/art514463-guildhall-art-gallery-rehang-breathes-life-into-its-major-victorian-art-collection|title=Guildhall Art Gallery rehang breathes life into a major Victorian art collection|last=Moss|first=Richard|date=23 January 2015|publisher=[[Culture24]]|accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> The model who sat for the painting was [[Alexa Wilding]].<ref name="Tate - Dante Gabriel Rossetti - Monna Vanna 1866">{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/rossetti-monna-vanna-n03054|title=Dante Gabriel Rossetti - Monna Vanna 1866|publisher=[[Tate]]|accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}}

{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[Image:Makie.jpg|thumb|Maki-e]] [[Image:Makie-enlargement.jpg|thumb|Maki-e enlargement]] {{nihongo|'''''Maki-e'''''|蒔絵||literally: sprinkled picture}} is [[Japanese lacquerware|Japanese lacquer]] sprinkled with gold or silver powder as a decoration using a ''makizutsu'' or a [[kebo]] brush. The technique was developed mainly in the [[Heian period]] (794–1185) and blossomed in the [[Edo period]] (1603–1868). Maki-e objects were initially designed as household items for court nobles; they soon gained more popularity and were adopted by royal families and military leaders as a symbol of power.
To create different colours and textures, maki-e artists use a variety of metal powders including gold, silver, copper, brass, lead, aluminum, platinum, and pewter, as well as their alloys. Bamboo tubes and soft brushes of various sizes are used for laying powders and drawing fine lines. As it requires highly skilled craftsmanship to produce a maki-e painting, young artists usually go through many years of training to develop the skills and to ultimately become maki-e masters. Kōami Dōchō (1410–1478) was the first lacquer master linked to specific works. His maki-e works used designs from various Japanese contemporary painters. Kōami and another maki-e master, Igarashi Shinsai, were originators of the two major schools of lacquer-making in the history of [[Japan]].
Takamakie (or "raised maki-e") is one of the three major techniques in maki-e making. Developed in the [[Muromachi period]] (1336–1573), the technique of takamakie involves building up design patterns above the surface through a mixture of metal powder, lacquer, and charcoal or clay dust.
Another special kind of maki-e is togidashi maki-e, where a black lacquer without oil is put on the metal decoration as an additional coat.
==References== * [http://www.kyohaku.go.jp/eng/dictio/data/shikki/makie.htm Lacquerware stories]/maki-e
==External links== * {{Commons category-inline|Maki-e}} * [http://global.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/359249/maki-e Maki-e] at [[Britannica]]

{{History of literature by era}} {{Zoroastrianism}} '''Middle Persian literature''' is the corpus of written works composed in [[Middle Persian]], that is, the [[Middle Iranian]] dialect of [[Persis|Persia proper]], the region in the south-western corner of the [[Iranian plateau]]. Middle Persian was the prestige dialect during the era of [[Sassanian Empire|Sassanid dynasty]].
The rulers of the [[Sassanid Empire]] (224–654 CE) were natives of that south-western region, and through their political and cultural influence, Middle Persian became a [[prestige dialect]] and thus also came to be used by non-Persian Iranians. Following the [[Rashidun conquest of the Sassanian Empire|Arab conquest of the Sassanian Empire]] in the 7th century, shortly after which Middle Persian began to evolve into New Persian, Middle Persian continued to be used by the Zoroastrian priesthood for religious and secular compositions. These compositions, in the Aramaic-derived [[Book Pahlavi]] script, are traditionally known as "Pahlavi literature". The earliest texts in Zoroastrian Middle Persian were probably written down in late Sassanid times (6th–7th centuries), although they represent the codification of earlier oral tradition.<ref>Sundermann, Werner. 1989. Mittelpersisch. P. 141. In ''Compendium Linguarum Iranicarum'' (ed. Rüdiger Schmidt).</ref> However, most texts, including the [[Zend|''zand'']] commentaries and translations of the [[Avesta|Zoroastrian canon]], date from the 9th to the 11th century, when Middle Persian had long ceased to be a spoken language, so they reflect the state of affairs in living Middle Persian only indirectly. The surviving manuscripts are usually 14th-century copies.<ref name="LLDescrip">{{cite web|url=http://linguistlist.org/forms/langs/LLDescription.cfm?code=pal|title=Linguist List - Description of Pehlevi|year=2007|publisher=Eastern Michigan University|location=Detroit}}</ref>
Other, less abundantly attested varieties of Middle Persian literature include the 'Manichaean Middle Persian' corpus, used for a sizable amount of [[Manichaean]] religious writings, including many theological texts, [[homily|homilies]] and hymns (3rd–9th, possibly 13th century). Even less-well attested are the Middle Persian compositions of [[Nestorian Christians]], evidenced in the [[Pahlavi Psalter]] (7th century); these were used until the beginning of the second millennium in many places in Central Asia, including [[Turfan]] (in present-day China) and even localities in Southern India.<ref>Sundermann, Werner. 1989. Mittelpersisch. P. 138. In ''Compendium Linguarum Iranicarum'' (ed. Rüdiger Schmidt).</ref>
==Subgroups== ==="Pahlavi" literature=== "Pahlavi literature traditionally defines the writings of the Zoroastrians in the Middle Persian language and Book Pahlavi script which were compiled in the 9th and the 10th centuries CE."<ref>{{citation|last=Cereti|first=C. G.|chapter=Middle Persian literature I: Pahlavi Literature|title=Encyclopedia Iranica|chapter-url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/middle-persian-literature-1-pahlavi|year=2009|location=New York|publisher=iranicaonline.org}}, accessed August 2010</ref>
The literary corpus in Middle Persian in [[Book Pahlavi]] consists of: * translations and commentaries (''[[Zend|zand]]'') of the [[Avesta]]. * other exegetical compositions on religious subjects. * compositions on non-religious subjects. These divisions are not mutually exclusive. Several different literary genres are represented in Pahlavi literature.
;''Zand'' texts The ''[[Zend|zand]]'' corpus include exegetical glosses, paraphrases, commentaries and translations of the [[Avesta]]'s texts. Although such exegetical commentaries also exist in other languages (including Avestan itself<!-- Boyce, TS 1984, p=4-->), the Middle Persian ''zand'' is the only to survive fully, and is for this reason regarded as 'the' ''zand''.<ref name="BoyceTS">{{citation|last=Boyce|first=Mary|title=Textual Sources for the Study of Zoroastrianism|year=1984|publisher=Manchester UP}}.</ref>
With the notable exception of the [[Yasht|''Yasht''s]], almost all surviving Avestan texts have their Middle Persian ''zand'', which in some manuscripts appear alongside (or interleaved with) the text being glossed. These glosses and commentaries were not intended for use as theological texts by themselves but for religious instruction of the (by then) non-Avestan-speaking public. In contrast, the Avestan language texts remained sacrosanct and continued to be recited in the Avestan language, which was considered a [[sacred language]].
;Other exegetical works The corpus of medieval texts of Zoroastrian tradition include around 75 works, of which only a few are well known: * the ''[[Denkard]]'', "Acts of Religion", is an encyclopedic compendium of Sassanid era beliefs and customs. * the ''[[Bundahishn]]'', "Original Creation", is an important source of information on Zoroastrian cosmogony. * Manushchihr's ''[[Dadestan-i Denig|Dadestan i Denig]]'' ("Religious Decisions") and [[Epistles of Manushchihr|''Epistles'']] * the ''Vichitakiha i Zatsparam'', the "Treatises of Zatsparam", by Manushchihr's brother Zatsparam. * the ''[[Book of Arda Viraf|Arda-Viraf Namag]]'' relates the dream-journey of a devout Zoroastrian (the 'Viraf' of the story) through the next world. * the ''[[Menog-i Khrad|Daedestan i Menog-i Khrad]]'', "Judgments of the Spirit of Wisdom", is an ''andarz'' text (a class of Iranian [[wisdom literature]]) in which a figure named Danag (lit: "wise, knowing") participates in a question-and-answer dialog with Menog-i Khrad, the Spirit of Wisdom. * the ''[[Jamasp Namag]]'', "Book of Jamaspi", also known as the ''Ayadgar i Jamaspig'' "(In) Memoriam of Jamasp", is a compendium of essential doctrine, together with basic myth, legend, history, and some pseudo-prophetic matters cast as a series of revelations by Jamasp through the model of a question-and-answer dialog with [[Vishtaspa|Vishtasp]]. * the ''[[Zand-i Wahman yasn]]'' is another pseudo-prophetic text, in this case cast as a question-and-answer dialog between Zoroaster and Ahura Mazda, in which the latter gives his prophet the ability to see into the future. * the ''[[Shikand-gumanic Vichar]]'', a partly apologetic and partly polemic review of other religions. * the ''[[Shayast ne-shayast]]'', "(on what is) Proper and Improper", a compilation of miscellaneous laws and customs regarding sin and impurity, with other memoranda about ceremonies and religious subjects in general.
;Secular compositions A manuscript known as the "miscellaneous codex" or ''MK'' (after Mihraban Kaykhusrow, the Indian Zoroastrian copyist who created it), dated to 1322 but containing older material, is the only surviving source of several secular Middle Persian works from the Sassanian period. Among the texts included in the unique ''MK'' are: * the ''[[Kar-Namag i Ardashir i Pabagan]]'' is a hagiography of [[Ardashir I]], the founder of the Sassanid dynasty * the ''Ayadgar i Zareran'', the "Memorial or Zarer", is the only surviving specimen of Iranian epic poetry composed in Middle Persian. * the ''[[Sahrestaniha i Eransahr|Shahrestaniha i Eranshahr]]'', is a catalogue of the four regions of the Sassanid empire with mythical and/or historical stories related to their founding. * several ''andarz'' texts, the Iranian type of [[wisdom literature]] containing advice and injunctions for proper behavior. * the ''Wizarishn i Chatrang'', "Explanation of Chess", also known as the ''Chatrang Namag'', is a humorous story of how an Indian king sent a game of chess to the Sassanid court to test Iranian wits, in response to which a priest invented backgammon to challenge the Indian king. * the ''[[Drakht-i Asurig|Drakht i Asurig]]'', "the Assyrian tree", is an originally Parthian poem recast into Book Pahlavi but retaining many Parthian phrases and idioms. * the ''Abdih ud Sahigih i Sagistan'' is a description of the "Wonders and Remarkable Features of Sistan". * the ''Khusraw va Redag'', "Khusraw and the Page", is an account of a conversation between the king and a young boy who would like to be a page. This work is a source of information on the sensual delights of the Sassanian court.
Especially important to cultural and law historians is the ''Madayan i Hazar Dadestan'', "Book of a Thousand Judgements", a 7th-century compilation of actual and hypothetical case histories collected from Sassanian court records and transcripts. Only a single manuscript of this unique text survives.
Scribes also created several glossaries for translating foreign languages. Of these, two have survived: * ''[[Frahang-i Pahlavig]]'', a glossary of common [[Heterogram (literature)|Aramaic heterograms]] (''[[huzvarishn]]'') used in written Middle Persian. * ''[[Frahang-i Oim-evak]]'', a dictionary of [[Avestan]] words and phrases.
Several other works, now lost, are known of from references to them in other languages. Works of this group include: * in about the 5th century, priests attached to the Sassanid court began to compile an immense chronicle, the ''Khwaday Namag'' ("Book of Kings"), a legendary genealogy of the Sassanid kings in which the Sassanians were dynastically linked to [[Vishtaspa]],<ref name="BoyceTS" /> i.e. Zoroaster's patron and the legendary founder of the mythological [[Kayanian dynasty]]. The original Middle Persian version of the chronicle has been lost, and the contents survive only through Arabic translations and in a versified New Persian version, the ''[[Shahnameh]]'' by Firdausi, finished around 1000 CE.<ref name="BoyceTS" /> * the ''Kalile va Demne'', a Middle Persian translation of the Indian [[Panchatantra]]. The Middle Persian work survives only as a translation into [[Syriac language|Syriac]] and two centuries later into Arabic by [[Abdullah Ibn al-Muqaffa|Ibn al-Muqaffa]]. * the ''[[Letter of Tansar]]'', a rationale for Ardashir's seizure of the throne. The letter was translated into [[Arabic language|Arabic]] in the 9th century by [[Abdullah Ibn al-Muqaffa|Ibn al-Muqaffa]], and from Arabic into [[New Persian]] in the 13th century ''History of Tabaristan'' by Ibn Isfandiar. * the ''Ayyatkar-i Anushirvan'', which has survived as an Arabic translation in a section of [[Ebn Meskavayh]]'s ''Tajarib al-Umam''.
===Other works=== <!-- Manichaean and Christian works go here -->
==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * [[Gilbert Lazard]], [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/poetry-iv-poetics-of-middle-persian The Poetics of Middle Persian], Encyclopædia Iranica (accessed August 2010) {{refend}}
==Full texts== *[http://www.avesta.org/ Avesta-Zoroastrian Archives], includes Middle Persian writings in English translation *[http://www.rahamasha.net/ Scholar Raham Asha's website], includes many texts in original and English translation (some also on the * [http://www.parsig.org/ancient-texts.html parsig.org]) *[https://www.scribd.com/zkassock A Large Online Pahlavi Library], contains pdfs of many Pahlavi manuscripts in its original script, many with transcriptions and translations. *[https://www.scribd.com/doc/141335939/kassock-pahlavi-reproductions-middle-persian-books-in-reprint Kassock Pahlavi Reproductions], a small company that provides many reprints of Pahlavi books and manuscripts. Kassock also writes guides for students learning Pahlavi for select books.
==External links== * [http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/hymn-of-the-pearl "Hymn of the Pearl"]
